awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of multi-use cryostat/magnet “Physical Properties Measurement System” for studying quantum materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Searching for new materials and engineering systems with desired quantum properties holds promise to enable leaps not only in fundamental solid-state physics but also in quantum information processing and quantum sensing. This project acquires a versatile shared-use system for studying the physical properties of new quantum-mechanical devices and materials at low temperatures and high magnetic fields. The modular and extensible nature of the system allows for a wide range of effects to be examined. At the same time, the turnkey nature of the system makes it well suited as a platform for training the next generation of scientific researchers, both in the context of classwork in experimental materials science and condensed-matter physics and for undergraduate and high-school students performing summer research programs in the laboratories of the scientists involved in the project. 

The project acquires a multi-use cryostat, with temperatures ranging from 1.8 to 400 K in its standard configuration and to 50 mK with an included dilution-refrigeration insert. Combined with a 14 T magnet, this enables measuring materials over a broad range of parameter space. The base capabilities of the system are leveraged by several measurement modules including magnetization, specific heat, and susceptibility to perform multimodal measurements of new quantum materials. Research projects include an extensive program on van der Waals heterostructures, where engineering strain into monolayer graphene has been shown to provide a wide range of control over the electronic correlation and magnetic states, and the construction of Moire superlattices built from multilayer graphene and transition metal dichalcogenides lead to exotic quantum phases. Magnetic susceptibility measurements in the sub-Kelvin regime characterize rare-earth antiferromagnets for use in high-efficiency quantum transduction devices. Another platform for quantum transduction, field-tuned superconducting resonators, are characterized via microwave impedance measurements. Rapid-cycle testing of magnetization and resistivity support characterizing a wide variety of correlated electronic and magnetic materials prior to ultra-fast optical measurements. Temperature-dependent Hall Effect measurements on patterned 2D plasmonic materials yield insight into the mobilities and damping pathways of the resonances. Combined electrical and magnetic measurements probe the electrochemistry of candidate materials for future battery cathode designs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Searching for new materials and engineering systems with desired quantum properties holds promise to enable leaps not only in fundamental solid-state physics but also in quantum information processing and quantum sensing. This project acquired a versatile shared-use "PPMS" system for studying a wide range of properties of new quantum-mechanical devices and materials at low temperatures and high magnetic fields. The modular and extensible nature of the system allows for a wide range of effects to be examined. The award period covered system acquisition and commissioning, and approximately one year of operation. The full set of capabilities included in the project proposal have been delivered and demonstrated performance to specification. Over the course of the first year of operation, research projects included:

  • Transistors built from 2-dimensional semiconductors are promising candidates for next-generation nano-and opto-electronic device applications. The PPMS system was used to measure such devices at low temperature and high magnetic field. In addition, the behavior of these materials can be controlled by supplying "twisted light" from a custom-built laser system.
  • In many magnetic materials for which quantum mechanics play an essential role, the behavior at temperatures below 1 Kelvin can be fundamentally altered by applying a magnetic field, one example of a so-called "quantum phase transition". Using the heat capacity and magnetic susceptibility capabilities of the system in combination with the ultra-low temperatures provided by the helium dilution refrigerator insert, the sensitivity to disorder of such quantum phase transitions was examined..
  • The behavior of materials can fundamentally change when the thickness is reduced to only a few atomic layers, often resulting in both a different crystal structure and exotic quantum states. The PPMS with the dilution refrigerator was used to observe superconductivity in one such material, LaSb2, at temperatures ranging from 1.4 K down to 0.6 K as the films are made thinner. The thinnest films see the superconductivity survive to unusually high magnetic fields. The PPMS with dilution fridge has given us the ability to probe these materials down to 50mK with high reliability, temperature stability and fast turnaround time. This system will continue to serve our research into novel materials by producing publication-quality, low temperature data while also giving the ability to rapidly screen samples before transferring to specialized instruments.
  • Pyrochlores are materials with a structure consisting of a complex interacting network of triangles. Because of this complexity, magnetic pyrochlores have a wide range of behaviors often dominated by quantum tunneling and quantum fluctuations. The high-field capabilities of the PPMS system were used to study one such material, ZeFe2O4, and determined the nature and extent of its unique magnetic ordering.
  • Nano-scale magnetic particles can have their surfaces coated with a variety of chemicals that allow them to controllably bond to substances such as chemotherapy agents. Filters constructed from magnetic materials can then be used to trap such particles, potentially protecting sensitive internal organs from the toxic agents. The magnetometry capabilities of the PPMS system were used to study the magnetic properties of a series of iron-based alloys used for the construction of such filters.
  • Quasicrystals, materials that are ordered but not truly periodic, can be found in meteorites or grown in the lab. The torque magnetometry capability of the system was used to study a series of lab-grown quasicrystals, investigating the role that shockwaves play in determining their structure and magnetic behavior. This sheds light on the processes which can lead to the formation of naturally-occurring quasicrystals. 

At the same time, the turnkey nature of the system makes it well suited as a platform for training the next generation of scientific researchers, especially for undergraduate and high-school students performing summer research programs. As part of Caltech?s SURF and WAVE programs, several undergraduates have been trained on the system, giving them experience both in the operation of cryostats and in the design and construction process for building specialized instruments for specific experiments.
